awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Connected Rapid Innovation Software System to meet Medtech Development Needs
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of artificial intelligence (AI)-driven technology aimed at enhancing interdisciplinary collaboration, mentorship, and talent searching in order to accelerate medical and biotechnological research and product development. A current search for experts commonly depends on word-of-mouth or internet search, which is often time consuming and may not be accurate. The proposed technology may overcome obstacles by 1) facilitating matchmaking to identify collaborators and mentors, and build teams in the context of a voluntary, technical workforce; 2) advancing the understanding of the factors leading to expert or mentor recommendation; and 3) identifying successes/failures in the development of device innovations. The goal of the proposed system is to create impactful, sustained connections within and across institutions, and enable researchers to conduct collaborative research and product deployment that will improve health. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a software system using natural language processing, machine learning, and deep learning to enhance interdisciplinary collaboration, mentorship, and talent identification in order to accelerate medical and biotechnological research and product development. It leverages narrative documents in the public domain and private corporations and performs data fusion across multiple siloed data sources.  The proposed innovation may enable users to effectively identify ranked collaborators, mentors, and similar medical products through the AI inference engine based on user's input such as the keywords and abstract. The proposed AI technology leverages distributed free-text databases for search performance and redundancy. Additionally, the this implementation of robust product regulatory pathways may meet the needs of early-stage med-tech developers regardless of their local development ecosystem and connections.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The current search for experts commonly depends on word of mouth or internet search, which is often time-consuming and may not be accurate. To address the problem, we have developed a technology, Expertise Knowledge Platform (EKP), which (1) facilitates automated entity matching between authors on the published articles and employees within an institution; (2) provides matchmaking to identify collaborators or mentors based on the user’s criteria; (3) recommends candidates who may respond to funders’ request for proposals to institutional administrators. We employed artificial intelligence (AI) and deep learning algorithms for the development. 

For entity matching, we demonstrated an F1 score of 97% matchmaking using PubMed publications between 2012 and 2023 and the employee database (n=121,447 employees). Currently, we provide publication productivity reports within departments at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP); compared to the manual curation of productivity reports, our entity matching enables a saving of two hours of staff time monthly. For matchmaking collaborators or mentors, we have deployed a web-based EKP interface at CHOP (Figure 1) since 2023, which is available to all CHOP employees. Users can enter search criteria following PubMed-like logical operator to narrow their search.  With the efficiency and accuracy of the EKP search, we are in the process of deploying EKP at the University of Pennsylvania to benefit more researchers outside CHOP. For the matchmaking between RFPs and researchers’ expertise (summarized in researchers’ biosketches), our study, which used 70 RFPs and 146 biosketches, demonstrated that an F1 score of 71.15% using BERT with cross-encoding and back translation technology. 

Overall, our EKP system facilitates impactful, sustained connections within and across institutions and enables researchers to conduct collaborative research that can further improves healthcare.

 


Last Modified: 04/30/2024
Modified by: Fuchiang Tsui

por.por_txt_cntn:
The current search for experts commonly depends on word of mouth or internet search, which is often time-consuming and may not be accurate. To address the problem, we have developed a technology, Expertise Knowledge Platform (EKP), which (1) facilitates automated entity matching between authors on the published articles and employees within an institution; (2) provides matchmaking to identify collaborators or mentors based on the users criteria; (3) recommends candidates who may respond to funders request for proposals to institutional administrators. We employed artificial intelligence (AI) and deep learning algorithms for the development.


For entity matching, we demonstrated an F1 score of 97% matchmaking using PubMed publications between 2012 and 2023 and the employee database (n=121,447 employees). Currently, we provide publication productivity reports within departments at the Childrens Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP); compared to the manual curation of productivity reports, our entity matching enables a saving of two hours of staff time monthly. For matchmaking collaborators or mentors, we have deployed a web-based EKP interface at CHOP (Figure 1) since 2023, which is available to all CHOP employees. Users can enter search criteria following PubMed-like logical operator to narrow their search.With the efficiency and accuracy of the EKP search, we are in the process of deploying EKP at the University of Pennsylvania to benefit more researchers outside CHOP. For the matchmaking between RFPs and researchers expertise (summarized in researchers biosketches), our study, which used 70 RFPs and 146 biosketches, demonstrated that an F1 score of 71.15% using BERT with cross-encoding and back translation technology.


Overall, our EKP system facilitates impactful, sustained connections within and across institutions and enables researchers to conduct collaborative research that can further improves healthcare.
